This set of exercises is a lot, but I assume you are already familiar with most of it (it's mostly practice material for the ones who aren't). Task 1 covers the language modeling and smoothing components of the lecture. Of specific interest (check these regardless of your experience): Task 8 discusses the Multinomial implementation of Naive Bayes which is covered in the book, and is different from NB discussed in the video lecture. The video lecture discussed the Bernoulli variant (restricted to binary counts), which is not covered in detail in the book. Note that smoothing also works differently for this variant (see Task 9). You can use this chapter from Introduction to Information Retrieval as reference text if you need one.

 Warm-up Questions

These questions are intended to prime your brain for the materials we will be covering in the videos below. They are optional, and there are no expectations wrt the answers.
Last week, we talked about representing language as frequencies in a bag-of-words model. As these typically represent language in an unordered fashion, without relations between words, they miss important characteristics of the data (e.g., "good" relating to "movie"). Can you think of simple (or less simple) ways to improve upon simply using these single words as features?
In the previous question, you might have opted for feature-engineering some interesting properties of the sentence, but the most common way of making richer contextual representations is by including -context- through encoding sequences of multiple words as a single feature. These are then added to the term matrix, and we get counts when the this now longer string occurs in a document. Can you think of issues with taking these larger contexts as features? Hint: language is creative and the chances of you saying something unique increases with the length of a sequence.
The longer the context, the less likely it is to appear outside of initial documents. Let's suppose that we don't have counts for "I drove my blue bike to work", but we did see "I drove my bike to work". Can you think of a way to combine information from these different (partially overlapping) sequences? What makes a particular word 'valid' given a context, or sequence of tokens (e.g., why â€œI drove my bikeâ€ and not â€œI drove my catâ€)? How large does a context need to be to give enough information, you think?
Finally, can you think of cultural or demographic differences that might affect the likelihood of a word occurring in a sentence? The sentence â€œI drove my bike to workâ€ might be a good one to use as an example.  How do you think such idiosyncrasies affect classifiers, and models that have to interpret / produce language?

Remember that WWWï»¿ to refers to a sequence (a tokenized string; could be a sentence, document, etc.), or array of an instance (aka an independent variable), and wiw_iwiâ€‹ï»¿ the numerical representation of the iiiï»¿-th element of the sequence (e.g., a single token, a bi-gram, etc.). A more general-purpose notation is xxxï»¿ and xix_ixiâ€‹ï»¿ respectively. Similarly, we use yyyï»¿ for a list or array of a target, or label (aka the dependent variable) and yiy_iyiâ€‹ï»¿ for it's iiiï»¿-th entry. We denote the whole feature (or vector) space by XXXï»¿, and a vector of an instance in this space by (e.g., the first instance) xâƒ—1\vec{x}_1x1â€‹ï»¿. If we want to distinguish two general vectors in the same formula (e.g., for distances) we use pâƒ—\vec{p}pâ€‹ï»¿ and qâƒ—\vec{q}qâ€‹ï»¿ instead. The empirical mean of an array is denoted by xË‰\bar{x}xË‰ï»¿ (or yË‰\bar{y}yË‰â€‹ï»¿), which can be calculated using 1nâˆ‘i=1nvi\frac{1}{n} \sum^n_{i=1}{v_i}n1â€‹âˆ‘i=1nâ€‹viâ€‹ï»¿ where viv_iviâ€‹ï»¿ is either xix_ixiâ€‹ï»¿ or yiy_iyiâ€‹ï»¿. Here, nnnï»¿ (can also be denoted as NNNï»¿) refers to our sample size (or length of the arrays). Remember that âˆ‘i=1n\sum^n_{i=1}âˆ‘i=1nâ€‹ï»¿ iterates over all positions in xxxï»¿ or yyyï»¿, and sums the result of this. This can also be denoted pairwise; for example, given x=[1,2]x = [1, 2]x=[1,2]ï»¿ and y=[1,4]y = [1, 4] y=[1,4]ï»¿ the result of âˆ‘i=1n(xiâˆ’yi)\sum_{i=1}^{n}(x_{i} - y_{i})âˆ‘i=1nâ€‹(xiâ€‹âˆ’yiâ€‹)ï»¿ is (1âˆ’1)+(2âˆ’4)(1 - 1) + (2 - 4)(1âˆ’1)+(2âˆ’4)ï»¿.

nnnï»¿-Gram Language Modeling

Remember that for bi-grams (wnâˆ’1,wnw_{n-1}, w_nwnâˆ’1â€‹,wnâ€‹ï»¿), we can estimate their probabilities from a particular corpus (the bigger, the more truthful to language as a whole) using maximum likelihood estimation:
P(wn âˆ£ wnâˆ’1)=C(wnâˆ’1, wn)C(wnâˆ’1).\begin{equation} P(w_n\ |\ w_{n-1}) = \frac{C(w_{n-1},\ w_n)}{C(w_{n-1})}. \end{equation} P(wnâ€‹ âˆ£ wnâˆ’1â€‹)=C(wnâˆ’1â€‹)C(wnâˆ’1â€‹, wnâ€‹)â€‹.â€‹â€‹
With Laplace smoothing, this looks like:
PLaplace(wn âˆ£ wnâˆ’1)=C(wnâˆ’1, wn)+1C(wnâˆ’1)+V,\begin{equation} P_{\text{Laplace}}(w_n\ |\ w_{n-1}) = \frac{C(w_{n-1},\ w_n) + 1}{C(w_{n-1}) + V}, \end{equation}PLaplaceâ€‹(wnâ€‹ âˆ£ wnâˆ’1â€‹)=C(wnâˆ’1â€‹)+VC(wnâˆ’1â€‹, wnâ€‹)+1â€‹,â€‹â€‹
where, VVVï»¿ is the size of the vocabulary. We can evaluate our language model using Perplexity:
PPâ¡(W)=âˆi=1N1P(wiâˆ£wiâˆ’1)N.\begin{equation} \operatorname{PP}(W)=\sqrt[N]{\prod_{i=1}^{N} \frac{1}{P\left(w_{i} \mid w_{i-1}\right)}}. \end{equation} PP(W)=Ni=1âˆNâ€‹P(wiâ€‹âˆ£wiâˆ’1â€‹)1â€‹â€‹.â€‹â€‹

Regression Prediction

Remember that for a 2-d space (1 feature, 1 target), the prediction of a linear regression is y^=Î²0+Î²1â‹…x1\hat{y} = \beta_0 + \beta_1 \cdot x_1y^â€‹=Î²0â€‹+Î²1â€‹â‹…x1â€‹ï»¿, where Î²0\beta_0Î²0â€‹ï»¿ is the intercept (or bias coefficient) and Î²1\beta_1Î²1â€‹ï»¿ the coefficient for the first feature (i.e., the slope of the line). Here, x1x_1x1â€‹ï»¿ is the value of the first (and only feature), but coefficients and features up until Î²nâ‹…xn\beta_n \cdot x_nÎ²nâ€‹â‹…xnâ€‹ï»¿ might be added. Let's assume we are given the following two documents represented by word frequencies:
doc (#)lit (x1)dank (x2)age (x3)152030271925\begin{array}{r|rrr} \hline \text{doc (\#)} & \text{lit}\ (x_1) & \text{dank}\ (x_2) & \text{age}\ (x_3) \\ \hline 1 & 5 & 20 & 30 \\ 2 & 7 & 19 & 25 \\ \hline \end{array}doc (#)12â€‹lit (x1â€‹)57â€‹dank (x2â€‹)2019â€‹age (x3â€‹)3025â€‹â€‹

Fitting Regression

Remember that we can determine the regression line given this data analytically, through:
Î²1=âˆ‘i=1n(xiâˆ’xË‰)(yiâˆ’yË‰)âˆ‘i=1n(xiâˆ’xË‰)2,\begin{equation} \beta_1 = \frac{\sum_{i=1}^{n}(x_{i}-{\bar{x}})(y_{i}-{\bar{y}})}{\sum_{i=1}^{n}(x_{i}-{\bar{x}})^{2}}, \end{equation}Î²1â€‹=âˆ‘i=1nâ€‹(xiâ€‹âˆ’xË‰)2âˆ‘i=1nâ€‹(xiâ€‹âˆ’xË‰)(yiâ€‹âˆ’yË‰â€‹)â€‹,â€‹â€‹
and:
Î²0=yË‰âˆ’Î²1â‹…xË‰,\begin{equation} \beta_0 = \bar{y} - \beta_1 \cdot \bar{x}, \end{equation}Î²0â€‹=yË‰â€‹âˆ’Î²1â€‹â‹…xË‰,â€‹â€‹
where xË‰,yË‰\bar{x}, \bar{y}xË‰,yË‰â€‹ï»¿ are the averages for our feature xxxï»¿ and target yyyï»¿.

Task 3

Determine the regression line for this data snippet of YouTube comments, where xxxï»¿ is represented as word frequencies, and yyyï»¿ as meta-data counts:
give-away (x1) upvotes (y) 51197121\begin{array}{ll} \hline \text{give-away}\ (x_1)\ & \text{upvotes}\ (y)\ \\ \hline 5 & 119 \\ 7 & 121 \\ \hline \end{array}give-away (x1â€‹) 57â€‹upvotes (y) 119121â€‹â€‹
Solution (Full)
xË‰=(5+7)/2=6,yË‰=(119+121)/2=120\bar{x} = (5 + 7) / 2 = 6, \quad \bar{y} = (119 + 121) / 2 = 120xË‰=(5+7)/2=6,yË‰â€‹=(119+121)/2=120ï»¿â€‹
Î²1=(5âˆ’6)â‹…(119âˆ’120)+(7âˆ’6)â‹…(121âˆ’120)(5âˆ’6)2+(7âˆ’6)2=22=1\beta_1 = \frac{(5 - 6)\cdot(119-120) + (7 - 6)\cdot(121-120)}{(5 - 6)^{2} + (7 - 6)^2} = \frac{2}{2} = 1Î²1â€‹=(5âˆ’6)2+(7âˆ’6)2(5âˆ’6)â‹…(119âˆ’120)+(7âˆ’6)â‹…(121âˆ’120)â€‹=22â€‹=1
Î²0=120âˆ’1â‹…6=114\beta_0 = 120 - 1 \cdot 6 = 114Î²0â€‹=120âˆ’1â‹…6=114
f(X)=114+1â‹…x1f(X) = 114 + 1 \cdot{x_1}f(X)=114+1â‹…x1â€‹ï»¿â€‹
You can confirm this is a good fit by plugging our 'train' values back in: (114 + 1 * 5) = 119 and (114 + 1 * 7) = 121.

Evaluating (Linear) Regression

Remember that we have the following metrics to evaluate a linear regression model, where NNNï»¿ is the amount of instances we have labels for (i.e., equal to the length of yyyï»¿ and y^\hat{y}y^â€‹ï»¿):
MAE=âˆ‘i=1Nâˆ£y^iâˆ’yiâˆ£N\begin{equation}MAE = \frac{\sum^N_{i=1} | \hat{y}_i - y_i |}{N}\end{equation}MAE=Nâˆ‘i=1Nâ€‹âˆ£y^â€‹iâ€‹âˆ’yiâ€‹âˆ£â€‹â€‹â€‹

RMSE=âˆ‘i=1N(y^iâˆ’yi)2N\begin{equation}RMSE = \sqrt{\frac{\sum^N_{i=1} (\hat{y}_i - y_i)^2}{N}}\end{equation}RMSE=Nâˆ‘i=1Nâ€‹(y^â€‹iâ€‹âˆ’yiâ€‹)2â€‹â€‹â€‹â€‹
R2=1âˆ’âˆ‘i=1N(yiâˆ’y^i)2âˆ‘i=1N(yiâˆ’yË‰)2\begin{equation}RÂ² = 1 -\frac{\sum^N_{i=1} (y_i - \hat{y}_i)^2}{\sum^N_{i=1} (y_i - \bar{y})^2}\end{equation}R2=1âˆ’âˆ‘i=1Nâ€‹(yiâ€‹âˆ’yË‰â€‹)2âˆ‘i=1Nâ€‹(yiâ€‹âˆ’y^â€‹iâ€‹)2â€‹â€‹â€‹

Task 4

Given y=[8,3,1]y = [8, 3, 1]y=[8,3,1]ï»¿ and y^=[4,3,2]\hat{y} = [4, 3, 2]y^â€‹=[4,3,2]ï»¿, calculate MAE, MSE, RMSE, and RÂ².
Solution (Full)
MAE=âˆ£4âˆ’8âˆ£+âˆ£3âˆ’3âˆ£+âˆ£2âˆ’1âˆ£3=4+0+13â‰ˆ1.667MAE = \frac{|4-8| + |3-3| + |2-1|}{3} = \frac{4 + 0 + 1}{3} \approx 1.667MAE=3âˆ£4âˆ’8âˆ£+âˆ£3âˆ’3âˆ£+âˆ£2âˆ’1âˆ£â€‹=34+0+1â€‹â‰ˆ1.667

Evaluating Classification

Remember that for classification, we are generally interested in how our classifier confuses predictions. This is the goal of a confusion matrix:
y^=1y^=0y=1TPFNy=0FPTN\begin{array}{l|ll} & \hat{y} = 1 & \hat{y} = 0 \\ \hline y = 1 & TP & FN \\ y = 0 & FP & TN \\ \end{array}y=1y=0â€‹y^â€‹=1TPFPâ€‹y^â€‹=0FNTNâ€‹â€‹
It might either classify something as negative (y^=0\hat{y} = 0y^â€‹=0ï»¿) while the actual label is positive (y=1y = 1y=1ï»¿), which we would refer to as a False (prediction validity) Negative (predicted label), and a positive prediction (y^=0\hat{y} = 0y^â€‹=0ï»¿) while the actual label is negative (y=0y = 0y=0ï»¿), as a False Positive. We can use these in ratios to produce various metrics:
Accuracy=TP+TNTP+FN+FP+TN\begin{equation} \text{Accuracy} = \frac{TP + TN}{TP + FN + FP + TN} \end{equation}Accuracy=TP+FN+FP+TNTP+TNâ€‹â€‹â€‹
Precision=TPTP+FP\begin{equation} \text{Precision} = \frac{TP}{TP + FP} \end{equation}Precision=TP+FPTPâ€‹â€‹â€‹
Recall=TPTP+FN\begin{equation} \text{Recall} = \frac{TP}{TP + FN} \end{equation}Recall=TP+FNTPâ€‹â€‹â€‹
FÎ² score=(1+Î²2)â‹…TP(1+Î²2)â‹…TP+Î²2â‹…FN+FP\begin{equation} F_\beta\ \text{score} = \frac{(1 +\beta^2) \cdot TP}{(1+\beta^2) \cdot TP + \beta^2 \cdot FN + FP} \end{equation}FÎ²â€‹ score=(1+Î²2)â‹…TP+Î²2â‹…FN+FP(1+Î²2)â‹…TPâ€‹â€‹â€‹

kkkï»¿-Nearest Neighbors

Remember that the kkkï»¿-NN algorithm is as follows:
Given: kkkï»¿, and a distance metric SSSï»¿.
At training (fitting) time, given: a training set XXXï»¿, and labels yyyï»¿ we simply 'remember them'.
At testing (inference) time, given: a test set TTTï»¿, we do the following:
For a given tâƒ—\vec{t}tï»¿ in TTTï»¿, for all xâƒ—n\vec{x}_nxnâ€‹ï»¿ in XXXï»¿, we calculate S(tâƒ—,xâƒ—n)S(\vec{t}, \vec{x}_n)S(t,xnâ€‹)ï»¿. This results in a list Stâƒ—S_{\vec{t}}Stâ€‹ï»¿ with distances, and thus closest neighbors, for instance tâƒ—\vec{t}tï»¿. We store each distance along with its original index nnnï»¿.
We rank this Stâƒ—S_{\vec{t}}Stâ€‹ï»¿ list, and take the top kkkï»¿ as the neighbors we are interested in,
We look up the indices nnnï»¿ for the top neighbors in yyyï»¿ (so we know their labels).
We choose the majority label of these top neighbors, and 'return' our prediction y^\hat{y}y^â€‹ï»¿ for tâƒ—\vec{t}tï»¿.

Task 6

Given k=1k = 1k=1ï»¿ and distance = Euclidean, X,yX, yX,yï»¿ and tâƒ—\vec{t}tï»¿ below, what is y^Å·y^â€‹ï»¿?
X=[2510326]y=[0,1]tâƒ—=âŸ¨4,3,8âŸ©X = \begin{bmatrix} 2 & 5 & 10 \\ 3 & 2 & 6 \\ \end{bmatrix} \quad y = [0, 1] \quad \vec{t} = \langle 4, 3, 8 \rangleX=[23â€‹52â€‹106â€‹]y=[0,1]t=âŸ¨4,3,8âŸ©
Solution (Full)
Remember that the Euclidean Distance is defined as:
âˆ‘i=1n(pâƒ—iâˆ’qâƒ—i)2\sqrt{\sum_{i=1}^{n}\left(\vec{p}_{i}-\vec{q}_{i}\right)^{2}}i=1âˆ‘nâ€‹(pâ€‹iâ€‹âˆ’qâ€‹iâ€‹)2â€‹
E(X0,tâƒ—)=(2âˆ’4)2+(5âˆ’3)2+(10âˆ’8)2=3.464\text{E}(X_0, \vec{t}) = \sqrt{(2 - 4)^2 + (5 - 3)^2 + (10 - 8)^2} = 3.464 E(X0â€‹,t)=(2âˆ’4)2+(5âˆ’3)2+(10âˆ’8)2â€‹=3.464ï»¿â€‹
E(X1,tâƒ—)=(3âˆ’4)2+(2âˆ’3)2+(6âˆ’8)2=2.450\text{E}(X_1, \vec{t}) = \sqrt{(3 - 4)^2 + (2 - 3)^2 + (6 - 8)^2} = 2.450E(X1â€‹,t)=(3âˆ’4)2+(2âˆ’3)2+(6âˆ’8)2â€‹=2.450ï»¿â€‹
The ranked neighbors are: [E(X1,tâƒ—)=2.450, E(X0,tâƒ—)=3.464][\text{E}(X_1, \vec{t}) = 2.450,\ \text{E}(X_0, \vec{t}) = 3.464 ][E(X1â€‹,t)=2.450, E(X0â€‹,t)=3.464]ï»¿, from which the top kkkï»¿ gives us X1X_1X1â€‹ï»¿ with y1=1y_1 = 1y1â€‹=1ï»¿.

Information Gain (Decision Trees)

Decision trees algorithms recursively make splits of the data, until they hit some criterion. Through this, they produce 'rules', which, at the end of the tree, we predict the majority label for the leftovers. In the lecture, we restrict ourselves to a single split of the data, and looked at Information Gain:
IG(Y,xn)=Entropy(Y)âˆ’âˆ‘vâˆˆxnâˆ£Yvâˆ£âˆ£Yâˆ£â‹…Entropy(Yv),\begin{equation} IG(Y,x_n) = \text{Entropy}(Y) - \sum_{v\in x_n} \frac{|Y_v|}{|Y|} \cdot \text{Entropy}(Y_v), \end{equation}IG(Y,xnâ€‹)=Entropy(Y)âˆ’vâˆˆxnâ€‹âˆ‘â€‹âˆ£Yâˆ£âˆ£Yvâ€‹âˆ£â€‹â‹…Entropy(Yvâ€‹),â€‹â€‹
where Entropy can be calculated using:
Entropy(S)=âˆ’âˆ‘i=1npiâ‹…logâ¡2pi.\begin{equation} \text{Entropy}(S) = - \sum^n_{i=1} p_i \cdot \log_2{p_i}. \end{equation}Entropy(S)=âˆ’i=1âˆ‘nâ€‹piâ€‹â‹…log2â€‹piâ€‹.â€‹â€‹
Here:
YYYï»¿ = The target column (label) we related the split quality to.
xnx_nxnâ€‹ï»¿ = The feature (word / token / etc) we are testing our split on.
vvvï»¿ = Each unique value of xxxï»¿, so if x=[0,1,2,1,1,2,3,1]x = [0, 1, 2, 1, 1, 2, 3, 1]x=[0,1,2,1,1,2,3,1]ï»¿, then vvvï»¿ might be 0, 1, 2, or 3.
YvY_vYvâ€‹ï»¿ = The subset of vvvï»¿ with respect to YYYï»¿, so if y=[0,1,0,1]y = [0, 1, 0, 1]y=[0,1,0,1]ï»¿ and x=[0,1,1,0]x = [0, 1, 1, 0]x=[0,1,1,0]ï»¿, then Yv=1Y_{v=1}Yv=1â€‹ï»¿ gives us y=[1,0]y = [1, 0]y=[1,0]ï»¿ and x=[1,1]x = [1, 1]x=[1,1]ï»¿.
âˆ£Yâˆ£|Y|âˆ£Yâˆ£ï»¿ and âˆ£Yvâˆ£|Y_v|âˆ£Yvâ€‹âˆ£ï»¿ = the sizes of the respective splits.
pip_ipiâ€‹ï»¿ is the probability of drawing label value iiiï»¿ from SSSï»¿.

Task 7

Given the dataset below, calculate the information gain of feature x0x_0x0â€‹ï»¿.
x0y102101102011\begin{array}{ll} \hline x_0 & y \\ \hline 1 & 0 \\ 2 & 1 \\ 0 & 1 \\ 1 & 0 \\ 2 & 0 \\ 1 & 1 \\ \hline \end{array}x0â€‹120121â€‹y011001â€‹â€‹
Solution (Full)
First, let's solve the left part â€” Entropy(Y)\text{Entropy}(Y)Entropy(Y)ï»¿. This we do like so:
Entropy(Y)=âˆ’(36â‹…logâ¡236+36â‹…logâ¡236)=1\text{Entropy}(Y) = - \left( \frac{3}{6} \cdot \log_2{\frac{3}{6}} + \frac{3}{6} \cdot \log_2{\frac{3}{6}} \right) = 1Entropy(Y)=âˆ’(63â€‹â‹…log2â€‹63â€‹+63â€‹â‹…log2â€‹63â€‹)=1
Then, we solve the right part, we calculate the entropy values for all values of x0x_0x0â€‹ï»¿:
Entropy(x0=0)=âˆ’(11â‹…logâ¡211)=0\text{Entropy}(x_0 = 0) = - \left( \frac{1}{1} \cdot \log_2{\frac{1}{1}} \right) = 0Entropy(x0â€‹=0)=âˆ’(11â€‹â‹…log2â€‹11â€‹)=0
Entropy(x0=1)=âˆ’(23â‹…logâ¡223+13â‹…logâ¡213)=0.918\text{Entropy}(x_0 = 1) = - \left( \frac{2}{3} \cdot \log_2{\frac{2}{3}} + \frac{1}{3} \cdot \log_2{\frac{1}{3}} \right) = 0.918Entropy(x0â€‹=1)=âˆ’(32â€‹â‹…log2â€‹32â€‹+31â€‹â‹…log2â€‹31â€‹)=0.918
Entropy(x0=2)=âˆ’(12â‹…logâ¡212+12â‹…logâ¡212)=1\text{Entropy}(x_0 = 2) = - \left( \frac{1}{2} \cdot \log_2{\frac{1}{2}} + \frac{1}{2} \cdot \log_2{\frac{1}{2}} \right) = 1Entropy(x0â€‹=2)=âˆ’(21â€‹â‹…log2â€‹21â€‹+21â€‹â‹…log2â€‹21â€‹)=1
Then we multiply those values by the sizes of their respective splits divided by the total dataset size, and put all the elements together:
IG(Y,xn)=1â‹†âˆ’(16â‹…0+36â‹…0.918+26â‹…1)=0.208â‹†=Entropy(Y)IG(Y,x_n) = 1^\star -\left( \frac{1}{6} \cdot 0 + \frac{3}{6} \cdot 0.918 + \frac{2}{6} \cdot 1 \right) = 0.208 \\ {}^\star = \text{Entropy}(Y)IG(Y,xnâ€‹)=1â‹†âˆ’(61â€‹â‹…0+63â€‹â‹…0.918+62â€‹â‹…1)=0.208â‹†=Entropy(Y)

Naive Bayes

Remember that:
y^=argâ¡maxâ¡yP(y)âˆj=1JP(xj âˆ£ y).\begin{equation} \hat{y} = \arg \max_y P(y) \prod_{j=1}^J P(x_j\ |\ y). \end{equation}y^â€‹=argymaxâ€‹P(y)j=1âˆJâ€‹P(xjâ€‹ âˆ£ y).â€‹â€‹
P(xj âˆ£ y)P(x_j\ |\ y)P(xjâ€‹ âˆ£ y)ï»¿ implies that for xjx_jxjâ€‹ï»¿, we get its conditional probability given every value of yyyï»¿, so 'how much does feature value xjx_jxjâ€‹ï»¿ occur under (for example) positive labels, and under negative labels'. Or, based on the equation from the book:
P^(xj âˆ£ y)=C(xj, y)âˆ‘xiâˆˆVC(xi,y),\begin{equation} \hat{P}(x_j\ |\ y) = \frac{C(x_j,\ y)}{\sum_{x_i \in V} C(x_i, y)}, \end{equation}P^(xjâ€‹ âˆ£ y)=âˆ‘xiâ€‹âˆˆVâ€‹C(xiâ€‹,y)C(xjâ€‹, y)â€‹,â€‹â€‹
where CCCï»¿ is a co-occurrence count of the two inputs, and VVVï»¿ is our vocabulary. We then multiply and sum these (product âˆ\prodâˆï»¿), and multiply them by prior P(y)P(y)P(y)ï»¿ â€” i.e., the probabilities of a value in yyyï»¿ occurring.
The algorithm follows the following steps:
Given: a smoothing factor Ïµ\epsilonÏµï»¿ (there are more hyperparameters such as the assumed distribution, but we don't discuss those):
At training (fitting) time, given: a dataset XXXï»¿, we do the following:
We get all probabilities (right-hand part after argmax) for our current data, and store it.
Any CCCï»¿, we optionally smooth with Ïµ\epsilonÏµï»¿ (typically +1). For the denominator this means that: âˆ‘xiâˆˆV(C(xi,y)+Ïµ)\sum_{x_i \in V} \left(C(x_i, y) + \epsilon\right)âˆ‘xiâ€‹âˆˆVâ€‹(C(xiâ€‹,y)+Ïµ)ï»¿, which is equal to (âˆ‘xiâˆˆVC(xi,y))+âˆ£Vâˆ£â‹…Ïµ\left(\sum_{x_i \in V} C(x_i, y)\right) + |V| \cdot \epsilon(âˆ‘xiâ€‹âˆˆVâ€‹C(xiâ€‹,y))+âˆ£Vâˆ£â‹…Ïµï»¿
At test (inference) time, given new instance tttï»¿, we:
Look up the pre-calculated probabilities for the features present in tttï»¿ (xjx_jxjâ€‹ï»¿), with respect to each possible label in yyyï»¿.
We return label with the highest probability (argâ¡maxâ¡y\arg \max_yargmaxyâ€‹ï»¿) as y^\hat{y}y^â€‹ï»¿.

Task 8

Given the dataset below, and the following instance: d=all was not greatd = \texttt{all was not great}d=all was not greatï»¿ â€” calculate y^\hat{y}y^â€‹ï»¿, counts are smoothed by +1.

Smoothing Across Techniques

As you saw in the previous Task, smoothing pops up in different parts of NLP where we use fractions or (log) probabilities. Each have their 'own' implementation. Two of such cases that are relevant to the current material are Bernoulli Naive Bayes (NB), and tfâ‹…idf\text{tf}\cdot\text{idf}tfâ‹…idfï»¿. For Bernoulli NB (explained in the lecture), we have the following distinction from Multinomial NB: the Bernoulli model estimates P^(w âˆ£ c)\hat{P}(w\ |\ c)P^(w âˆ£ c)ï»¿ as the fraction of documents of class cccï»¿ that contain word wwwï»¿. In contrast, the Multinomial model estimates P^(w âˆ£ c)\hat{P}(w\ |\ c)P^(w âˆ£ c)ï»¿ as the fraction of tokens or fraction of positions in documents of class cccï»¿ that contain word wwwï»¿. Because of this distinction, we smooth the denominator of Bernoulli NB with a constant of 2, as this class only models occurrence under a label, and nonoccurence (rather than all counts of all features). So Laplace MLE for this model looks like:
PLaplace(w âˆ£ c)=C(w,c)+1C(c)+2\begin{equation} P_\text{Laplace}(w\ |\ c) = \frac{C(w, c) + 1}{C(c) + 2} \end{equation}PLaplaceâ€‹(w âˆ£ c)=C(c)+2C(w,c)+1â€‹â€‹â€‹
For tfâ‹…idf\text{tf}\cdot\text{idf}tfâ‹…idfï»¿, we also apply smoothing to avoid the undefined logâ¡\loglogï»¿ of zeroes, and/or division by zero. In Exercise 1, the most rudimentary tf\text{tf}tfï»¿ smoothing version was applied. Typically, we either implement sublinear term frequency scaling, as a weighted term frequency (wf \text{wf}\ wf ï»¿) like so:
wft,d={1+logâ¡tft,d if tft,d>00 otherwise \begin{equation} \mathrm{wf}_{t, d}= \begin{cases}1+\log \mathrm{tf}_{t, d} & \text { if } \mathrm{tf}_{t, d}>0 \\ 0 & \text { otherwise }\end{cases} \end{equation}wft,dâ€‹={1+logtft,dâ€‹0â€‹ if tft,dâ€‹>0 otherwise â€‹â€‹â€‹
Notice that, compared to here, there is no zero smoothing, and we do not add-one inside the logâ¡\loglogï»¿ (as the log of 1 is also undefined), but simply apply it to non-zero values. We leave the zeroes as zeroes. This gives us wft,dâ‹…idft\mathrm{wf}_{t, d} \cdot \mathrm{idf}_{t}wft,dâ€‹â‹…idftâ€‹ï»¿. Also, again compare to the equation in the 1st exercise, the idf\text{idf}idfï»¿ value can still give us zero divisions. Hence, add-one smoothing is typically applied in the idf\text{idf}idfï»¿ portion, like so:
idft=1+logâ¡bN+1dft+1\begin{equation} \text{idf}_t = 1 + \log_b \frac{N + 1}{ \text{df}_t + 1} \end{equation}idftâ€‹=1+logbâ€‹dftâ€‹+1N+1â€‹â€‹â€‹
Remember that b=10b = 10b=10ï»¿, i.e., logâ¡b=logâ¡10=lgâ¡\log_b = \log_{10} = \lglogbâ€‹=log10â€‹=lgï»¿.

Given the following example from Exercise 1:

This gives us the left portion (1+lnâ¡(2))\left(1 + \ln \left(2 \right)\right)(1+ln(2))ï»¿. The right portion is calculated using this equation. Here, cat occurs in all three documents, so its dft=3\text{df}_t = 3dftâ€‹=3ï»¿. NNNï»¿ is the number of documents, so 3.
